When did WHO declare COVID-19 a pandemic: The World Health Organization (WHO) officially declared COVID-19 a pandemic on March 11, 2020. This declaration came after the disease, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, had spread to multiple countries across the world with sustained community transmission. At that time, there were more than 118,000 cases in 114 countries, and 4,291 people had died. The WHO Director-General, Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, made this announcement, emphasizing the severity and spread of the disease while also expressing concern about 'the alarming levels of inaction' in response to the outbreak.

Who were the astronauts on Apollo 11?:
The Apollo 11 mission, which achieved the first human landing on the Moon, had three astronauts on board:

1. Neil Armstrong - Commander. He became the first person to step onto the lunar surface on July 20, 1969, with his famous words, "That's one small step for [a] man, one giant leap for mankind."

2. Edwin "Buzz" Aldrin - Lunar Module Pilot. He joined Armstrong on the lunar surface about 19 minutes after Armstrong's first step, becoming the second human to walk on the Moon.

3. Michael Collins - Command Module Pilot. He remained in lunar orbit aboard the Command Module "Columbia" while Armstrong and Aldrin explored the lunar surface in the Lunar Module "Eagle."

The mission launched from Kennedy Space Center in Florida on July 16, 1969, and returned safely to Earth on July 24, 1969, fulfilling President John F. Kennedy's goal of landing humans on the Moon and returning them safely before the end of the 1960s.
